com.github.upthewaterspout.fates.core.states

Class Fates

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.github.upthewaterspout.fates.core.states.Fates

  • public class Fates
extends java.lang.Object
    A testing harness for running tests many times, exploring the affects of different decisions on the test.

    Users should construct a RepeatedTest and pass the test to this harness. The harness is responsible for running the test repeatedly.

    The algorithm for exploring possible decisions can be set using setExplorer(Supplier) Algorithms may explore all possible decisions or some subset of decisions, it is up to the algorithm. Currently the only implementation of StateExplorer is DepthFirstExplorer, which explores all possible decisions.

    This harness assumes that each time the test is run, if the same decision is made twice in a row it will lead to the same test state. If a the explorer makes the same choice twice, but is presented with different results, the test will fail.

    Example: 

     
   new Fates().explore(decider -> {
     int a = decider.decide(1,3,5);
     int b = decider.decide(2,4);
     assertIsEven(a * b);
   });

    • Method Detail

      • setExplorer

        public Fates setExplorer(java.util.function.Supplier<StateExplorer> explorerSupplier)
        Configure the StateExplorer that should be used. The default is DepthFirstExplorer
        Parameters:
        explorerSupplier - A supplier for the explorer to use. Each call to explore(RepeatedTest) will invoke this supplier to create a new instance of the potentially stateful explorer class.
        Returns:
        this

      • explore

        public void explore(RepeatedTest test)
             throws java.lang.Exception
        Execute a test multiple times, exploring some or all of the possible states of the test
        Parameters:
        test - the test to explore. It will be run many times.
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if the test fails

      • setTrace

        public Fates setTrace(boolean trace)
        Enable execution traces. When this is turned on, a trace of all thread scheduling points from the first pass through the test will be printed to standard out. This is useful for debugging how many decision points exist within a test.
        Parameters:
        trace - true if traces should be enabled
        Returns:
        this
